summary.p: Even though Sturm has never written to Bullinger before, he recommends the young bearer [Gerhard thom Camph], because he requested it. The [people of Zurich] should not let themselves be more upset than necessary by Luther's curse [“Short Confession”] - for the sake of the torn church. He regrets that [the Swiss Confederates] brought forth the vehement poem against Osiander; certainly, [Osiander] started the dispute, but the poet has bitten in a very painful way; one must not give the opponents any further [opportunity for attack]! He asks for a benevolent reception of his candid letter. Greetings.

div.p: The young man wishes to be commended to you by me. I could not deny him this service, even though I have never written to you before, but I had to comply with the honorable wish of a very studious and excellent young man, whom I indeed commend to you again and again.
Luther has published a very bitter curse. I ask that you do not allow yourselves to be more disturbed by such an angry speaker at this time than is fair.
Dedicate this to the torn church, and let us strive, even against opposing men, to somehow restore its torn members.
A vehement poem also came from you against Osiander, and I would not wish that it had been done; but he was the first to injure, yet this poet has bitten more painfully.
Let us not give the enemies greater occasion than has been given so far; forgive me for writing to you more freely than I should.
I do not wish to be a monitor, but a supplicant, and I beseech you to grant something. I wish and desire that you all be safe and sound, and especially your old father Pellicanus. Farewell.
In Straßburg, the eighth of November 1544.
To the most learned and excellent man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger.
